title: Brexit votes in the United Kingdom by social class 2016
summary: This grouped bar chart represents 4 different Responses on X-axis for 2 groups Remain, and Leave. On the Y-axis it shows their corresponding Share of respondents.

Response Upper Working-Class (C2) had the maximum Share of respondents among all 2 groups, and it was for Leave. The minimum Share of respondents was observed in Response Lower Working-Class (DE) for Remain.

The maximum Share of respondents for Remain that was found in Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) was 1.58 times larger than the minimum Share of respondents observed in Response Lower Working-Class (DE).
On average, the Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) had the highest Share of respondents for all 2 groups Remain, and Leave. Whereas Lower Working-Class (DE) had the lowest average Share of respondents.
min_summary: This grouped bar chart shows Share of respondents on the Y-axis for 4 different Responses for 2 groups Remain, and Leave that are presented on the X-axis.
Out of all 2 groups, Leave had the highest Share of respondents for Response Upper Working-Class (C2) and Remain had the lowest Share of respondents for Response Lower Working-Class (DE).
mid_summary: This grouped bar chart represents 4 different Responses on X-axis for 2 groups Remain, and Leave. On the Y-axis it shows their corresponding Share of respondents.

Response Upper Working-Class (C2) had the maximum Share of respondents among all 2 groups, and it was for Leave. The minimum Share of respondents was observed in Response Lower Working-Class (DE) for Remain.

The maximum Share of respondents for Remain that was found in Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) was 1.58 times larger than the minimum Share of respondents observed in Response Lower Working-Class (DE).
On average, the Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) had the highest Share of respondents for all 2 groups Remain, and Leave. Whereas Lower Working-Class (DE) had the lowest average Share of respondents.
max_summary: This grouped bar chart shows Share of respondents on the Y-axis for 4 different Responses for 2 groups Remain, and Leave that are presented on the X-axis.
Out of all 2 groups, Leave had the highest Share of respondents for Response Upper Working-Class (C2) and Remain had the lowest Share of respondents for Response Lower Working-Class (DE).
Among all the Responses, Remain had the highest Share of respondents 57.0 in Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) and lowest value 36.0 in Response Lower Working-Class (DE).

The maximum Share of respondents for Remain that was found in Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) was 1.58 times larger than the minimum Share of respondents observed in Response Lower Working-Class (DE).
Among the groups, Remain had the biggest difference in Share of respondents. Where the maximum Share of respondents was 1.58 times larger than the minimum Share of respondents.
Averaging all 2 groups Remain, and Leave, the Response Upper Middle-Class (AB) is the maximum Share of respondents and Lower Working-Class (DE) is the minimum Share of respondents.
